author: acid0003
content:
Release the code for the merge, but leave it disabled. Announce that if no bugs are found that the next merge will only defuse the bomb, and enable the merge using the existing code. Give people enough time to mess with it, have weekly merges on testnets forking from mainnet, and offer an 8 figure bug bounty for a list of specific classes of issues people could find.
If you don't have a final version out for months, you have not given people enough time to take a serious look at reviewing the code. 
Ethereum's market cap is $400T, major bugs will destroy a portion of this value since people would lose faith in the dev's ability to run Ethereum. This is still true if you respond to them immediatly and appropriatly. Offer a small portion of what would be lost to protect against that, from the Ethereum Foundation's wallet.

author: pietjepuk
content:
> Also I‚Äôm really against how rushed it is. Personally to me it seems crazy to run both clients and maintain two databases. I know that won‚Äôt change but it does indicate that things are being rushed such that an imperfect product is being shipped. Not a developer so I don‚Äôt know how much extra work it is but seems a lot better to just have one replacement client than build a second client that duplicates a lot of the work done by first one and run it in parallel. 
What to you might seem "rushed" to me seems as "careful". Making single monolithic clients right away is just introducing needless complexity (for now anyway), and if you were to do that on the same timeline would make it rushed imo.

 There will no doubt someday be a monolithic client that does all, or other types of convenience wrappers that make it seem you're running a single client. Do note that there has been exploration in the (opposite) direction of splitting up the EL client, most notably I remember Erigon/Silkworm/Akula (talking about) going there. Either way a client (monolithic or not) will have internal APIs/boundaries as well, with people (mostly) working on their own side of the fence.

I do wonder what you mean with "duplicates a lot of the work done by first one". What exact parts are you talking about here?

author: chris2_2_2
content: For instance needed to run two syncs

author: pietjepuk
content:
What about it? You think that would be different with a single client?

To elaborate on that, there's two chains with two separate histories. The only way I can think of getting rid of duplicate sync requirements is to have a regenesis. Again rather unneeded complexity for switching to PoS imo, although eventually definitely a possibility to get rid of sync requirements for the pre-PoS era. Not sure how likely it is to be implemented though.

author: m.kalinin
content: The Merge replaces tiny (in terms of programming complexity) PoW with sophisticated PoS consensus algorithm. The complexity of creating a monolithic client is gonna be huge, it's much bigger than supporting Engine API as a communication channel between the pair of clients. And it's likely to have two parts of the team -- one with well understanding of consensus part, another with the same regarding execution part. From this standpoint having a separation of concerns between clients and client teams does seem natural to me

author: ajsutton
content: I'd say the most important thing though is that the current system lets us progress much more incrementally.  More incremental means smaller change sets and reduced risk. That's a pretty fundamental part of effective software engineer practices. The other part is not leaving testing until the end - it's integrated through the whole process which is why we don't need to spend two years in a code freeze while testing happens.

author: potuz
content: On the context of duplication. Not as a complaint on the merge itself but as an honest question cause I don't understand how the EL syncs. We will be keeping completely separate p2p stacks right? I see how the CL will be gossiping blocks, attestations and the such on one network. Also how the EL will be sending transactions and keeping a mempool on it's own (let's not enter in the complications of relays). But also the EL will be sending back and forth payloads on their own, right? If they're syncing or missing blocks they'll request them from their own peers, right? This seems like an area that can be optimized in the future as there's no need for independent discovery, handshaking, etc. I understand that the naive approach would add complexity as a bidirectional communication would be required between layers. But I suspect the overall complexity will decrease as one of the two sides would completely disappear
